facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 400 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave from the order dated December 20, 1958, of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur in Case No. 21/XV of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 400 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the order dated December 20, 1958, of the Life Insurance Tribunal, Nagpur in Case No. 21/XV of 1958.

facts.text: The United India Life Assurance Company Ltd. was incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1882, with principal object of carrying on life insurance business and was registered as an insurer under the Life Insurance Act, VI of 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The United India Life Assurance Company Ltd.-hereinafter called the Company-incorporated under the Indian Companies Act, 1882, with the principal object of carrying on life insurance business in all its branches was registered as an insurer under the Life Insurance Act, VI of 1938 for carrying on life insurance business in India.

facts.text: On July 15, 1955, at an extraordinary General Meeting of shareholders, resolution passed to donate Rs. 2 lakhs from Shareholders Dividend Account to M. Ct. M. Chindambaram Chettyar Memorial Trust.

anchor.surface_text: On July 15, 1955, at an extraordinary General Meeting of the share- holders of the Company, the following resolution, amongst others, was passed - Resolved that a donation of Rs. 2 lakhs be sanctioned from out of the Shareholders Dividend Account to the M. Ct. M. Chindambaram Chettyar Memorial Trust proposed to be formed with the object, inter alia, of promoting technical or business knowledge, including knowledge in insurance.

facts.text: Appellants 2 to 4 were Directors of the Company on the date of the resolution dated July 15, 1955, with appellant 4 being the Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: Resolved further that the Directors be and are hereby authorised to pay the aforesaid sum to the Trustees of the aforesaid Trust when it is formed. On the date of this resolution, appellants 2 4 were Directors of the Company, appellant 4 being the Chairman of the Board of Directors.

facts.text: On December 6, 1955, five settlers including the Company executed a deed establishing the M. Ct. M. Chindambaram Chettyar Memorial Trust with Rs. 25,000 transferred to trustees.

anchor.surface_text: On December 6, 1955, five settlers  including the Company  executed a deed reciting that the settlers desired to establish a charitable trust for companymemorating the name of the Late M. Ct. M. Chidambaram Chettyar befitting his services to various institutions and organisations with which he was companynected, and to industry companymerce, finance, art and science in general and the great encouragement he gave to education, training, research and promotion of human relationship, and with that object the settlers had declared, transferred and delivered to the trustees a sum of Rs. 25,000/

facts.text: Appellants 2, 3 and 4 were nominated as trustees under the deed, and first appellant was appointed a trustee under clause 8.

anchor.surface_text: Appellants 2, 3 4 were the trustees numberinated under the deed of trust, and the first appellant was appointed a trustee under cl. 8 of the deed.

facts.text: Company paid initial instalment of Rs. 5,000 to trustees and balance Rs. 1,95,000 on December 15, 1955, in pursuance of July 15, 1955 resolution.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the resolution dated July 15, 1955, of the Directors of the Company made an initial instalment of Rs. 5,000/- to the trustees and the balance of Rs. 1,95,000/- was paid on December 15, 1955.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 was brought into force on July 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1956, the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956, was brought into force.

facts.text: September 1, 1956 was notified as the appointed day under LIC Act, on which all assets and liabilities of the Company transferred to Life Insurance Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: September 1, 1956 was numberified as the appointed day, and on that day, all the assets and liabilities of insurers including the Company stood transferred to and vested in the Life Insurance Corporation.

facts.text: On September 30, 1957, Life Insurance Corporation called upon appellants to refund Rs. 2 lakhs received by trust from Company.

anchor.surface_text: On September 30, 1957, the Life Insurance Corporationwhich will hereinafter be referred to as the Corporation-called upon the appellants to refund the amount of Rs. 2 lakhs recei-ved by the trust from the Company in December, 1955,

facts.text: Appellants denied liability to refund by letter dated December 10, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellants by their letter dated December 10, 1957, having denied liability -to refund the amount,

facts.text: On March 14, 1958, Corporation applied to Life Insurance Tribunal for order directing trustees to pay Rs. 2 lakhs with 6% interest.

anchor.surface_text: the Corporation applied on March 14, 1958 to the Life Insurance Tribunal companystituted under the Life Insurance Corporation Act for an order that the trustees be ordered jointly and severally to pay to the Corporation the sum of Rs.2 lakhs with interest thereon at the rate of six per cent per annum from the date of payment to the trustees.

facts.text: By order dated December 20, 1958, Life Insurance Tribunal directed appellants to pay Rs. 2 lakhs jointly and severally within 15 days, else 6% interest.

anchor.surface_text: By order dated December 20, 1958, the Tribunal directed the appellants to pay jointly and severally Rs. 2 lakhs within fifteen days from the date of service of the order, and in default to pay interest thereon at the rate of 6 per tent per annum till the date of realisation.

facts.text: Corporation alleged the July 15, 1955 resolution and payments were ultra vires, not authorized by Memorandum, not in interests of Company.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged by the Corporation that the resolution dated July 15, 1955 as well as the payments made in pursuance thereof were ultra vires the Company and void and of numbereffect in law, that the Memorandum of the Company did number authorise such payment, that making of such a donation was number in the interests of the Companys business number was it a generally recognised method of companyducting the business and by the donation numberdirect or substantial advantage accrued to the Company.

facts.text: Appellants claimed Directors authorized by Articles to make donations, payment from Shareholders Dividend Account which is exclusive property of shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants by their written statement submitted that the Directors of the Company were authorised by the Articles of Association of the Company to make donations towards any charitable or benevolent object or for any public, general or useful object, that the amount of Rs. 2 lakhs was paid out of the Shareholders Dividend Account which was distinct and separate from the general assets of the Company, and under the Articles of Association money standing to the credit of the Shareholders Dividend Account being the exclusive property of the shareholders

facts.text: Supreme Court held the donation resolution was ultra vires the Memorandum of Association.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that the resolution donating the funds of the Company was number within the objects mentioned in the Memorandum of Association and on that account it was ultra vires.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellants as directors and trustees personally liable to refund the amount.

anchor.surface_text: As office bearers of the Company who were responsible for passing the, resolution ultra vires the Company, they will be personall liable to make good the amount belonging to the Company which was unlawfully disbursed in pursuance of the resolution.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts. Appeal dismissed.

facts.text: Articles 116 and 117 of Company's Articles of Association provide for constitution of Shareholders Dividend Account from surplus.

anchor.surface_text: The material clauses of the Articles of Association of the Company relating to the companystitution of the Shareholders Dividend Account are Arts. 116 and 117. Article 116 reads Interest on the paid-up capital at the rate of six per cent per annum simple for each of the years companyered by the Valuation Period shall from a first charge on and be deducted from the surplus remaining and the said amount shall become the exclusive property of the shareholders and shall be carried over to the Shareholders Dividend Account.

facts.text: No dividend was declared by the July 15, 1955 resolution; it was a donation.

anchor.surface_text: By the resolution passed by the Company on July 15, 1955, it was resolved to donate Rs. 2 lakhs to the Trust. Undoubtedly the amount was payable out of the Shareholders Dividend Account but by the impugned resolution numberdividend was declared.

issues.text: What is the true effect of the resolution dated July 15, 1955, and the character of the Shareholders Dividend Account?

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary in the first instance to ascertain the true effect of the resolution dated July 15, 1955, and the character of the Shareholders Dividend account. The material clauses of the Articles of Association of the Company relating to the constitution of the Shareholders Dividend Account are Arts. 116 and 117.

issues.text: Whether the resolution donating Rs. 2 lakhs amounted to a declaration of dividend payable to shareholders or a donation by the company?

anchor.surface_text: By the resolution passed by the Company on July 15, 1955, it was resolved to donate Rs. 2 lakhs to the Trust. Undoubtedly the amount was payable out of the Shareholders Dividend Account but by the impugned resolution no dividend was declared.

issues.text: Whether the resolution of the Company and acceptance by trustees constituted a contract supported by consideration?

anchor.surface_text: The contention raised by counsel for the appellants that the resolution of the Company and the acceptance thereof by the appellants as trustees of the Trust constituted a contract is, in our judgment, futile.

issues.text: Whether the donation was within the objects of the Memorandum of Association and not ultra vires?

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that the resolution donating the funds of the Company was not within the objects mentioned in the Memorandum of Association and on that account it was ultra vires.

issues.text: Whether the appellants (directors and trustees) were personally liable to refund the amount?

anchor.surface_text: The only question which remains to be considered is whether the appellants were personally liable to refund the amount paid to them.

issues.text: Whether a second appeal lay to the High Court?
What is the scope of the High Court's power of revision under s. 35 of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952?
Whether notice under s. 106 Transfer of Property Act was validly served or necessary?
Whether the tenancy had expired by efflux of time obviating need for notice?
Whether inducting a new sub-tenant in place of an old one constitutes sub-letting under s. 13(1)(b) of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952?

holdings.text: The resolution dated July 15, 1955 was a donation from the Shareholders Dividend Account and not a declaration of dividend payable to shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: By the resolution passed by the Company on July 15, 1955, it was resolved to donate Rs. 2 lakhs to the Trust. Undoubtedly the amount was payable out of the Shareholders Dividend Account but by the impugned resolution no dividend was declared.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution explicitly donates amount; no recommendation by directors or declaration as required by Articles 119, 123, 124; distinguished from interim dividend declared at same meeting.

holdings.text: Funds in Shareholders Dividend Account are company property until dividend declared; shareholders have no proprietary interest therein prior to declaration.

anchor.surface_text: The expression exclusive property of the shareholders only emphasizes that in the Shareholders Dividend Account the policy-holders have no interest it means that the fund is divisible only among shareholders, policy-holders having no right to participate therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arts. 116-117 set apart surplus but no individual proprietary interest until declaration per recommendation of directors (Arts. 122-124); follows Bacha F. Guzdar case.

holdings.text: Resolution of company and acceptance by trustees did not constitute a contract for want of consideration.

anchor.surface_text: The contention raised by counsel for the appellants that the resolution of the Company and the acceptance thereof by the appellants as trustees of the Trust constituted a contract is, in our judgment, futile.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No valuable consideration under s.2(d) Contract Act; mere acceptance of gratuitous donation not consideration; payment made pursuant to prior resolution.

holdings.text: Donation resolution ultra vires Memorandum of Association as not within objects, incidental or conducive thereto.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that the resolution donating the funds of the Company was not within the objects mentioned in the Memorandum of Association and on that account it was ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: MoA cl.III limits to life insurance business, investments per Articles; donation not incidental/conducive (no proximate connection, indirect benefit insufficient); follows Ashbury, Egyptian Salt, Tomkinson.

holdings.text: Appellant directors and trustees personally liable to refund amount disbursed pursuant to ultra vires resolution.

anchor.surface_text: As office bearers of the Company who were responsible for passing the, resolution ultra vires the Company, they will be personally liable to make good the amount belonging to the Company which was unlawfully disbursed in pursuance of the resolution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directors responsible for ultra vires act personally liable; trustees benefited without consideration; s.15(2) LIC Act empowers Tribunal to order responsible parties to refund.

holdings.text: High Court power of revision under s.35 Delhi & Ajmer Rent Control Act wider than CPC s.115 but not appellate jurisdiction; interferes if decision not according to law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'according to law' covers miscarriage of justice from legal error; follows Hari Shankar, Bell Co.; not precisely definable.

holdings.text: No notice under s.106 TPA required where tenancy expires by efflux of time.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease deed fixed one-year term (admitted); post-expiry statutory tenancy but no notice needed for termination by efflux.

holdings.text: Inducting new sub-tenant in place of prior sub-tenant constitutes sub-letting under s.13(1)(b) Rent Control Act after Act commencement without written consent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.13(1)(b)(i) applies to any sub-letting post-Act commencement, not confined to first; new sub-tenants inducted by tenant after prior ones vacated.

holdings.text: Civil Judge's decree not according to law as wrongly held notice required despite tenancy expiry by efflux.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Even assuming no second appeal, s.35 revision justified as decision erroneous on law (notice unnecessary).

precedents.citation: Bacha F. Guzdar Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1 1955 1 S.C.R. 876

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in Bacha F. Guzdar Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1 1955 1 S.C.R. 876 The argument of companynsel for the appellants that the meeting held on July 15, 1955, was a meetingof the shareholders, and when the shareholders resolved to donate an amount of Rs. 2 lakhs out of the Shareholders Dividend Account they must be deemed to have resolved upon the destination of a part of the Fund to which they were entitled, has therefore numberforce.

precedents.case_name: Bacha F. Guzdar v Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: True position of a shareholder: entitled to participate in profits if and when company declares dividend
precedents.cited_holding: He has undoubtedly a further right to participate in the assets of the company which would be left over after winding up but not in the assets as a whole.

anchor.surface_text: The Memorandum of Association must like any other document be construed according to accepted principles applicable to the interpretation of all legal documents and numberrigid canon of companystruction is to be applied to such a document. Like any other document, it must be read fairly and its import derived from a reasonable interpretation of the language which it employs. Egyptian Salt Soda Company v. Port Said Salt Association 1 .

anchor.surface_text: Guinness v. Land Corporation of Ireland 1882 22 Ch. DI, In re. South Durham Brewery Co. 1885 31 Ch. D. 261 . Their Lordships agree that in such cases the two documents must be read together at all events so far as may be necessary to explain any ambiguity appearing in the terms of the memorandum, or to supplement it upon any matter as to which it is silent.

anchor.surface_text: In re. South Durham Brewery Co. 1885 31 Ch. D. 261 . Their Lordships agree that in such cases the two documents must be read together at all events so far as may be necessary to explain any ambiguity appearing in the terms of the memorandum, or to supplement it upon any matter as to which it is silent. There is however numberambiguity in the relevant terms of the Memorandum of Association.

precedents.case_name: In re South Durham Brewery Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Memorandum and articles to be read together

anchor.surface_text: In Tomkinson v. South Eastern Railway 1 it was held that a resolution passed by the shareholders of a Railway Company authorising the Directors to subscribe pound 1000 out of the Companys funds towards a donation to the Imperial Institute was ultra vires, even though the establishment of the Institute would benefit the Company by causing an increase in passenger traffic over their line.

precedents.case_name: Tomkinson v South Eastern Railway Co
precedents.cited_proposition: Donation by company to unrelated institute ultra vires even if indirect benefit
precedents.cited_holding: Subscription to Imperial Institute not incidental to railway business despite potential traffic increase.

precedents.citation: Re. Birkback Permanent Benefit Building Society 1 1912 2 Ch. 183

anchor.surface_text: Where a Company does an act which is ultra vires, numberlegal relationship or effect ensues therefrom. Such an act is absolutely void and cannot be ratified even if all the shareholders agree. Re. Birkback Permanent Benefit Building Society 1 1912 2 Ch. 183. The payment made pursuant to the resolution was therefore unauthorised

precedents.case_name: Re Birkbeck Permanent Benefit Building Society
precedents.cited_proposition: Ultra vires acts are void and cannot be ratified even by all shareholders

precedents.citation: Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdhari Lal Chowdhury, 1962 Supp. I C. R. 933

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed by the learned counsel on a decision of this Court in Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdhari Lal Chowdhury, 1962 Supp. I C. R. 933 and Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj, 1938 40 Bom. L. R. 125, referred to. Held, further, that the tenant had sub-let the premises within the meaning of s. 13 1 b i of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Hari Shankar v Rao Girdhari Lal Chowdhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Scope of High Court revision power under s.35 Delhi Rent Control Act wider than CPC s.115
precedents.cited_holding: Phrase 'according to law' refers to overall decision; larger powers than s.115 CPC.

precedents.citation: Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj, 1938 40 Bom. L. R. 125

anchor.surface_text: Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdhari Lal Chowdhury, 1962 Supp. I C. R. 933 and Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj, 1938 40 Bom. L. R. 125, referred to.

precedents.case_name: Bell & Co Ltd v Waman Hemraj
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court revision power under analogous provision; not to substitute own view lightly
precedents.cited_holding: Court ought not interfere merely because it might arrive at different conclusion.
